title: Type mismatch after upgrading to ReactNative 0.65.0-rc.3
body:
I upgraded react-native from 0.63.4 to **0.65.0-rc.3**

but when I build android package I get this error ;

**> Task :react-native-navigation:compileReactNative63ReleaseKotlin FAILED**

e: /mobile-branch/node_modules/react-native-navigation/lib/android/app/src/main/java/com/reactnativenavigation/views/element/animators/ReactImageMatrixAnimator.kt: (31, 21): Type mismatch: inferred type is ScalingUtils.ScaleType? but ScalingUtils.ScaleType was expected

e: /mobile-branch/node_modules/react-native-navigation/lib/android/app/src/main/java/com/reactnativenavigation/views/element/animators/ReactImageMatrixAnimator.kt: (32, 21): Type mismatch: inferred type is ScalingUtils.ScaleType? but ScalingUtils.ScaleType was expected

The rows at `ReactImageMatrixAnimator.kt` :
```
           val fromBounds = calculateBounds(from, parentScaleX, parentScalyY)
            hierarchy.actualImageScaleType = InterpolatingScaleType(
                    getScaleType(from), ------> 31
                    getScaleType(to), ---------> 32
                    fromBounds,
                    calculateBounds(to),
                    PointF(from.width * parentScaleX / 2f, from.height * parentScalyY / 2f),
                    PointF(to.width / 2f, to.height / 2f)
            )
```

title: Support request for interceptTouchOutside for Modals
body:
## üöÄ Feature

Is it possible to add support for interceptTouchOutside also for modals, in the same way it is implemented for overlays?

## Motivation

It would be awesome to be able to pass touches outside modal, in order to support well-integrated custom modals, bottom sheets, and other particular behaviors.
In our specific case, it would permit us to implement an advanced music player animation integrated with other modals, [such as this](https://media4.giphy.com/media/nXBtUARrO5YNGgvHJA/giphy.gif). Using an overlay instead, in fact, will show other modals under the player itself.

Thank you in advance

title: [WIP] ReactNative modals android support
body: support overlays and match ios

title: Hiding the bottom navigation bar on Android creates a gap at the bottom of the view
body: ## üêõ Bug Report When the navigation bar is set to `visible: false` (as described [here](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/api/options-navigationBar#visible)), it still takes up space. Nothing is able to render in the gap. ### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)? Yes. ## To Reproduce 1. Clone the demo (link below) 2. `cd navigation-bar-demo` 3. `yarn install` 4. `react-native run-android` If the blue background doesn't appear on the first run, you may need to run `react-native run-android` a second time. ## Expected behavior The blue background should extend all the way to the bottom of the view. ## Actual Behavior The blue background stops where the navigation bar would be if it were visible. ## Your Environment - React Native Navigation version: 7.17.1 - React Native version: 0.64.2 - Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): Android - Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): Android 11 on Pixel 4 Emulator ## Reproducible Demo https://github.com/dillpixel/navigation-bar-demo

title: [Android] Exit app when call function Navigation.pop() on componentDidmount()
body:
## üêõ Bug Report

i have two screens, when i press button to move from screen A to screen B and make call function Navigation.pop(componentId) in componentDidMount() on screen B, function the screen freezes and doesn't show screen B and cannot back to screen A, then I press the phone's back button, the app is exited. in two screens I only show one letter to know which screen I'm on

## To Reproduce


1. Create two screens, A and B, on screen A create button to Navigation to screen B, on screen B  call function Navigation.pop(componentId) in componentDidMount().
2. Press the exit button on the phone.
4. app exited.

## Expected behavior

when i call the function Navigation.pop() the screen freezes and nothing can be done. then I press the back button on the phone, the app is exited



## Your Environment

<!-- Include as many relevant details about the environment you experienced the bug in -->

- React Native Navigation version: 3.0.0
- React Native version: 0.60.5
- Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): Android
- Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): Device  version Debug & Release

title: Cannot Remove a Previously Set TopBar Background Component
Installing with npm v7 fails for React Native 0.64
body: ## üêõ Bug Report Installing library with React Native 0.64 and npm7 fails due to a peer dependency error. ### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)? Yes ## To Reproduce (Write your steps here:) 1. Install node and npm 7: `npm install -g npm@7` 2. Create a new react native project, telling the script to use npm as the package manager: `npx react-native init NavigationProject --npm` 3. Go into the new folder and try to install react-native-navigation: `cd NavigationProject; npm install react-native-navigation` ## Expected behavior Install should succeed ## Actual Behavior Install failed. On further inspection, this is due to the following: - react-native-navigation has a dependency on `remx@3.x.x` - This resolves to `remx@3.0.611`, which has a dependency on `mobx-react@^5.2.3` - This resolves to `mobx-react@5.4.4`, which has a peerDependency on `react@"^0.13.0 || ^0.14.0 || ^15.0.0 || ^16.0.0"` (note: _not_ react@17) Since React Native 0.64 has a peer dependency on React 17, this is the version installed when running `npx react-native init`. [npm v7's default behaviour when a peer dependency can't be fulfilled is to fail the installation](https://github.com/npm/rfcs/blob/latest/implemented/0025-install-peer-deps.md), which is what is happening in this case: `mobx-react@5.4.4` does not list react@17 as a peerDep. There is a workaround, to run `npm install --legacy-peer-deps` which reverts back to npm v6 behaviour - but this isn't particularly elegant. ## Your Environment - React Native Navigation version: 7.18.0 - React Native version: 0.64.2 - Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): both - Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): N/A - Node version: 14.16.1 - npm version: 7.9.0 ## Reproducible Demo (Paste the link to an example repo and exact instructions to reproduce the issue.) https://github.com/studiozeffa/react-native-navigation-peerdep-issue - Clone the above - Make sure you are using npm v7 (`npm install -g npm@7`) - Run `npm install` This will reproduce the issue.

title: [Android] Screen size not adjusted properly when navigationBar is hidden
body:
## üêõ Bug Report

Screen size remains the same size when navigationBar is hidden, leaving a background colored box where the navigationBar used to be.

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)?

Yes.

## To Reproduce

1. Start with playground app
2. In app.ts, edit the setRoot() call so that that the Options stack is directly below root, removing bottomTabs and the other screens
3. Start the app, click the "Toggle Navigation bar visibility" button

## Expected behavior
The usable screen should expand towards the bottom when the navigation bar disappears. This works when using the bottomBar.

## Actual Behavior
The navigation bar disappears, but the area remains unusable. Scrolling the view moves the buttons under the navigation bar area instead of letting them hit the bottom of the screen.

Attached are screenshots showing the situation.

![scrolled_down](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3696793/123985021-6a4abe00-d9c5-11eb-8d67-53255fef9bda.png)
![scrolled_up](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3696793/123985031-6b7beb00-d9c5-11eb-887c-bb64f6f82eda.png)

## Your Environment


- React Native Navigation version: 7.16.0
- React Native version: 0.63.1
- Platform: Only tested on Android
- Device info: Android 8.1 simulated and device

## Reproducible Demo

```
git clone https://github.com/hooplab/react-native-navigation.git rnn_navbar
cd rnn_navbar
git checkout navbar_bug
```

Follow [Playground instructions](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/playground-app) to start app

title: Recursive call of navigationButtonPressed when popStackOnPress: false

labels.name: user: requires reproduction
labels.description: This issue requires a reproduction before maintainers can work on it

body:
## üêõ Bug Report

navigationButtonPressed is called after Navigation.pop, while it should only be called when there is a press on a navigation button. (happens only on iOS 11 (probably 12 too))

## To Reproduce

1. In Navigation default options, set:
```
backButton: {
       showTitle: false,
       popStackOnPress: false
},
```
2. Init a navigation root with one screenA. Push screenB to the stack. 
3. On both screens, register to events with; `Navigation.events().bindComponent(this)` and listen to navigation button press event:
```
navigationButtonPressed({ buttonId }: { buttonId: string }) {
        if (buttonId === "RNN.back") {
            Navigation.pop(this.props.componentId);
        }
    }
```
4. Press back button while on screenB.
5. This will trigger `navigationButtonPressed` of screenB. Since we manually pop there, this will trigger again the `navigationButtonPressed` on screenA. If we didn't manually pop there, there would be no recursive call. 
So somehow, the  Navigation.pop calls the `navigationButtonPressed` of previous screens in the stack. 


## Expected behavior

As happening on android and ios 14, `Navigation.pop` shouldn't recursively call the `navigationButtonPressed` of other screens


## Your Environment

- React Native Navigation version: 7.14.0
- React Native version: 0.63.4
- Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): IOS
- Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): Both simulator and device, debug and release versions, iOS 11 (probably 12 too)

title: `passedProps` are never passed on `Navigation.setRoot` when `bottomTabs` are provided

`passedProps` are never passed on `Navigation.setRoot` when `bottomTabs` are provided 

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)?

I am working on a minimal reproducible example, but I was trying to understand why my `passedProps` were never reaching my component, and discovered that the acts of passing some `bottomTabs` to `Navigation.setRoot` prevents `passedProps` from ever reaching the component.

## Expected behavior

`passedProps` are available in the component, even when `bottomTabs` are provided.

## Actual Behavior

`passedProps` are not available (only contains the `componentId`) when `bottomTabs` are provided

title: Reusing a component ID with setStackRoot causes empty passProps on Android
body:
## üêõ Bug Report

On Android, calling `setStackRoot` with a layout containing a component ID that is already in the current stack does not properly send `passProps` to the "updated" component.

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)?

Yes.

## To Reproduce

1. Push a component with a specific ID (`id: 'StackRoot1'` for this example) onto a stack
2. Call `setStackRoot` on the same stack, passing a `Layout[]` containing in the "history" (in other words, not as the current visible component) a component with the same ID (`StackRoot1`) and some `passProps`.
3. Press back or gesture to navigate "back" to `StackRoot1`.
4. On Android, observe the new `StackRoot1` component does not have the given `passProps`; on iOS, observe the new `StackRoot1` renders correctly.

## Expected behavior

`StackRoot1` correctly receives the `passProps` assigned in the `setStackRoot` call.

## Actual Behavior

On Android, `passProps` are not passed.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/305292/121088115-deb98500-c7aa-11eb-9145-b9620176a8c2.mp4

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/305292/121088127-e37e3900-c7aa-11eb-9739-fe9a386a993b.mp4

## Your Environment

- React Native Navigation version: 7.16.0
- React Native version: 0.63.2
- Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): Both
- Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): 
    - Pixel 3XL running Android 11
    - iOS simulator of an iPhone 12 running iOS 14.5

## Reproducible Demo

https://github.com/jmcountryman/react-native-navigation/tree/setStackRoot-passProps ([diff](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/compare/master...jmcountryman:setStackRoot-passProps))

1. Launch the app and choose "SideMenu".
2. Choose "Open Left".
3. In the left menu choose "Push", and observe the `componentId` displayed in the center stack is "StackRoot1".
4. In the left menu choose "Set center stack root" (which [sets the center stack](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/compare/master...jmcountryman:setStackRoot-passProps#diff-6a9be939e1dc67090cf4ae0d02509b916c1464c3e46f79fe5bb66169449b6412R62-R98) to a layout with 2 components, both with `passProps`) and close the left menu.
5. Observe the "top" component has a `customProp` value.
6. Press back or gesture to navigate back once.
7. On Android, observe the `StackRoot1` component does not have `passProps`, despite being [specified](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/compare/master...jmcountryman:setStackRoot-passProps#diff-6a9be939e1dc67090cf4ae0d02509b916c1464c3e46f79fe5bb66169449b6412R68-R70) in the call to `setStackRoot`. On iOS, observe the `passProps` appear correctly on `StackRoot1`.

title: setStackRoot causes pop event on iOS
body:
## üêõ Bug Report

On iOS, calling `setStackRoot` causes a `pop` event to be fired, which does not happen on Android (see videos in "Actual Behavior").

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)?

Yes.


## To Reproduce

In the playground app:
1. Comment out or remove [this line](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/blob/a365c46/playground/src/screens/LifecycleScreen.tsx#L91) in LifecycleScreen.tsx
1. Launch the app and choose "Stack".
1. Choose "Push Lifecycle Screen".
1. Choose "Screen popped events".
1. Choose "OK" on the "Screen popped event" modal (this one is expected behavior)
1. Choose "Set Stack Root"
1. On iOS, observe a second "Screen popped event" modal; on Android, observe no "Screen popped event" modal.


## Expected Behavior

No `pop` event is fired, or a `pop` event is fired on both platforms.


## Actual Behavior

A `pop` event is fired only on iOS.

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/305292/120865662-15e22900-c554-11eb-9a59-95dfbe8365de.mp4

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/305292/120865563-e6cbb780-c553-11eb-927d-e1e7516cd513.mp4


## Your Environment

- React Native Navigation version: 7.16.0
- React Native version: 0.63.2
- Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): Both
- Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): 
    - Pixel 3XL running Android 11
    - iOS simulator of an iPhone 12 running iOS 14.5


## Reproducible Demo

https://github.com/jmcountryman/react-native-navigation/tree/setStackRoot-pop-event ([diff](https://github.com/wix/react-native-navigation/compare/master...jmcountryman:setStackRoot-pop-event))

title: dotIndicator is shown on the next tab when badge in null on ios
fix: Only animate modals if they're not presented as `pageSheet` or `formSheet`
body:
Modals can have custom animations via `animations.showModal` or `animations.dismissModal`. This works fine for Modals presented in the following presentation style:

```
    overFullScreen
    overCurrentContext
    currentContext 
    popover 
    fullScreen
    none
```

but once you try animating modals with either `pageSheet` or `formSheet` presentation style, the animation goes crazy (goes beyond top, leaves blank see-thru area at the bottom)

This PR disables animation options for modals presented as page- or form-sheets to avoid this mistake. This means, for `pageSheet` and `formSheet` modals you cannot have custom content animations. Element transitions and Shared element transitions still work as expected.

title: Updated state not available in navigationButtonPressed method in a functional component
Issue when enabling waitForRender on setRoot
Shared Element Transition broken with safe area
body:
## üêõ Bug Report

The Shared Element Transition seems to not animate to the correct bounds.


Here's a video of the SET breaking on a phone that has left and right "edges" 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15199031/117459200-6eb9a400-af4b-11eb-83a6-1cfda49d6711.mp4

In this case I think the problem is that the screen absolute coordinates are used, which are not equal to the coordinates relative to the React Root view and they extend beyond those screen "edges":

![](https://cdn57.androidauthority.net/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/waterfall-displays-curved-edges-glass-1-1200x675.jpg)

(just assuming things here)

Here's another case of the bounds animation failing, this is a regular phone without any "safe areas", just the 24px statusbar:

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15199031/117459759-0a4b1480-af4c-11eb-84ae-1e5e34049c97.MP4

Here the image seems to be a bit higher up than it should be, looks to me as if it were exactly twice the statusbar moved up. Maybe there's a `- STATUS_BAR_HEIGHT` somewhere where it should be a `+ STATUS_BAR_HEIGHT` instead, just assuming things again. You can also see that after I fast-refresh the view, it goes into the correct place, so it has to be an issue with the RNN SET.

Maybe `statusBar: { drawBehind: true }` or `statusBar: { visible: false }` is not respected here?

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)?

yea

## To Reproduce

1. Create Shared Element Transition
1. Try it on phones with Safe Areas, or in my case just a regular Huawai P10

## Expected behavior

It should exactly animate to the bounds of the target react view

## Actual Behavior

it animates to some wrong coordinates.

## Your Environment


- React Native Navigation version: 6f7c2d9f75b5fb653452f903d822429eed429f51
- React Native version: 0.64.1
- Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): Android
- Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): all

title: Use native SpringAnimation implementation for each  platform
body:
## üöÄ Feature

See issue : #7044
### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing)?

yes

## Motivation

Today `SpringInterpolator` is based on third party calculations for spring force, which did not work, has "jumps" in animations for different spring configuration.

## Pitch

Use the native `SpringAnimation` implementation for each platform and write a unique `SpringInterpolator` that has the platform native `SpringAnimation` implementation in the implementation.

The platform might include such an interpolator, no need to write one,

- Change the JS API to support platform terminology on the native side (options-parser).
- On the native side, we might use one SpringInterpolator in order to achieve other interpolators through the config, like linear, overshoot, accelerate, etc. 
- Preset like configurations.
- Less code.
- Support a wide range of interpolations easily via a simple config of the animation.

@guyca wdyt?

title: Back button not popping current view after half-swiping right to go back
body:
## üêõ Bug Report

On IOS, the back button seems to fail to pop the current view after you have slightly dragged the current view to go back, but let go too early or drag back.

### Have you read the [Contributing Guidelines on issues](https://wix.github.io/react-native-navigation/docs/meta-contributing/)?

Yes

## To Reproduce

1. Create a stack navigator with a root component and title "Screen A"
2. Push a new screen into the stack with the back button enabled and with title "Screen B"
3. From the left edge of the screen, slightly drag to the right as if you were to go back to the previous screen, but let go after like a centimeter so it automatically moves back to it's original position (and thus staying on the current screen). Dragging to the right and dragging back to the left has the exact same effect.
4. Now click the back button in the topbar

## Expected behavior

The top screen gets popped and you arrive back at the root stack component

## Actual Behavior

You stay on the current screen. Strangely enough the topbar *does* correctly switch to the state of the root component (so the topbar correctly goes back to "Screen A" while your current screen component stays on "Screen B".

## Your Environment

- React Native Navigation version: 7.13.0
- React Native version: 4.14.0
- Platform(s) (iOS, Android, or both?): IOS
- Device info (Simulator/Device? OS version? Debug/Release?): Iphone 6, iOS 12.1, Debug

title: Tab Bar Text Still Cuts Off

labels.name: user: requires reproduction
labels.description: This issue requires a reproduction before maintainers can work on it

body:

### I am using the updated library version

But still it is replicating
